content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player who is comfortable taking risks and embracing challenges, I would approach this game strategically while keeping the long-term payoff in mind. In 75 rounds, there will be 37.5 times (approximately) where both of us can pick R or B simultaneously because neither of us wants to be at a significant disadvantage in the long run.

Given that picking R yields a higher reward when the opponent picks B (40$ vs 0$), it seems more advantageous to choose R initially, hoping the opponent will pick B as well, and then switch strategies over time to ensure we have a balanced number of R and B picks in the long run.

However, since the opponent is anonymous, there's no way to predict their behavior or whether they are also aiming for a balanced outcome. To maximize my overall payoff, I would still start with R (as it provides a higher reward when the opponent chooses B), but I would be prepared to switch strategies if needed to ensure a more even distribution of R and B picks over the course of 75 rounds.

So, I'll choose {R} initially and adjust my strategy as I observe the opponent's choices. This approach gives me the best chance of achieving a balance between picking R and B while also taking advantage of the higher reward when the opponent chooses B.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

By switching strategies now, I can increase my overall payoff in the future by taking advantage of potential opportunities presented by the opponent's choices. In the long run, I hope to have more rounds where both of us pick B or R simultaneously, ensuring a relatively even distribution of each choice and maximizing my potential earnings.

By maintaining flexibility in my strategy and being prepared to adjust as needed, I can maximize my overall payoff while staying adaptable to the opponent's choices. This approach will help me make informed decisions that take advantage of potential opportunities for higher rewards throughout the game.
